channel.title: Fasting
channel.description:
What's the longest any of you have gone without eating for? Did that accompany any physical or cognitive effects?
I'm currently at 49 hours and I feel fine as if I had eaten an hour ago.

item.title: Fasting
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

Why would you fast without a clue about it? Don’t talk bad about fasting if you do not know how to do it properly (yes, there’s more too it than just ‘not eating’). I fast every day of my life. I follow an intermittent fasting protocol, particularly the one made popular by Martin Berkhan (see; www.leangains.com, the 16:8 eating protocol, however I do 18:6 and occasionally go to 20:4).

While this is different too what you’re describing, I have sometimes done the ESE protocol. (Eat, stop, eat). Basically it’s 24 hour fasting every other day. I didn’t particularly like this protocol but lots do. What is making you feel bad when you first start fasting is the ghrelin response; you’ve been regularly eating all you life and all of a sudden you stop - your body is not used too this. It takes a little bit of time to adjust your ghrelin hormone.

I can honestly say after adjusting to an IF eating protocol, I have never felt better. I never feel lethargic during the day, I sleep amazingly well (who doesn’t like to sleep after gorging yourself on food?), and I am so much more mentally clear and energetic during my fasting window. Now, for the first month of switching to a fasting eating method, it did suck - I felt ill a fair bit. But after 2 weeks I started feeling better and better. Now I can eat, not eat, and it doesn’t matter. During my eating window, I can literally eat and eat and not get full, but don’t get hungry.

Read full topic

I recommend that no one tries it. I’m still feeling the ill effects over 24 hours after eating again.

item.title: Fasting
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’m not sure if it’s scientifically accurate or just conventional wisdom, but I’ve heard in the past that you can survive three minutes without oxygen, three days without water, and three weeks without food (sufficient body fat being available, of course).

Once you start to ration water while acting properly to survive (i.e., minimising activity, remaining in shade, etc) you can survive on as little as 250 - 300mL per day iirc.

Read full topic

item.title: Fasting
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

You’re right. I meant fasting; I just couldn’t think of the word at the time. I ended up going 62 hours without eating by which point I was close to passing out. The feeling of hunger actually goes away after day the first 24 hours and the idea of eating started to make me feel sick. I didn’t do this to try and lose weight. Biologically I understand that my body will start eating muscle and that I will retain more fat now that I’m eating again.

Read full topic

item.title: Fasting
item.dc:creator: @LilXCj LilXCj
item.description:
@LilXCj wrote:

I seriously wonder about my generation who has high metabolism like myself when it comes to eating. In high school I rarely heard that most people needed to watch their weight because they could eat anything and on the other side, people just didn’t care and packed it on. Of my generation, it seems like we’re a lot smaller in comparison to our parents (in general). I wonder if it doesn’t have anything to do with the metabolism but a bit more about what’s really in our foods these days…

On topic, however, I’ve never personally tried to fast. I like food too much.

Read full topic
